content.question: A certain type of legal proceeding has three possible outcomes: in favor of party A, in favor of party B, or not in favor of either party. The outcomes are expected to be 40 percent, 20 percent, and 40 percent, respectively. A random sample of 40 cases is selected from a certain judge to investigate whether the judge’s outcomes are consistent with the expected outcomes. A chi-square goodness-of-fit test is conducted, and the value of the chi-square test statistic is <math alttext="chi square equals 9.19" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>9.19</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with a corresponding <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value of 0.01. Assuming the conditions for inference were met, which of the following is the correct interpretation of the <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value?

choices.label: There is a 1 percent chance that the company’s claim is correct.
If the null hypothesis is true, there is a 1 percent chance that the company’s claim is correct.
If the null hypothesis is true, there is a 1 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of 9.19.
If the null hypothesis is true, there is a 1 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of at least 9.19.
There is a 1 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of at least 9.19.

content.answer: If the null hypothesis is true, there is a 1 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of at least 9.19.
